I know that at the beginning of a noun, when the *hamzat-al-wasl* in the definite article الْ is pronounced, it is always pronounced as "al-" (i.e. with a *fatha*). However, I have encountered other words (verbs or indefinite nouns) where the *hamzat-al-wasl* is sometimes pronounced with a *kasra*, or even a *damma*, instead of a *fatha*.
Visually, there is nothing to distinguish the *hamzat-al-wasl* in any of these cases; they are written exactly the same. Is there some general rule which would let me know how I should be pronouncing *hamzat-al-wasl* in cases where it *is* pronounced (rather than absorbed by the preceding vowel as would normally be the case)? Or is this simply a matter where I would need to learn and memorize the exceptions as they come up?
My primary concern for this is reciting the Qur'an, so I am particularly interested in the rules as per classical Arabic.
How is hamzat-al-wasl pronounced at the beginning of speech?

It is true that in historical textual witnesses many words, indeed most of them, were often written without dots (or wer only incompletely equipped with dots). In fact, some manuscripts are (almost entirely) devoid of dots at all. What we get in these manuscripts and teastimonies is the bare *rasm*, i.e., the skeleton of the word, like كىٮ , which could be *kuntu* or *kataba*, and so on.
In many cases this will be no problem for a learned scribe or reader, as the context will usually provide enough pieces of information for what the word could (or should) be. For example, if you read اں كىٮ it should be clear that after the conjunction *an* you would expect a verb in a subjunctive state which would rule out *kataba* (which is perfect tense) as a correct interpretation of the otherwise ambiguous *rasm*.
This being said, it is clear that there is a certain (sometimes high) degree of ambiguity that arises from missing dots. So, scribes often added at least some dots (but not all of them) to disambiguate more sufficiently.
Nowadays, scholars working with historical texts nonetheless have a lot to do in finding out how the dotless words should properly be interpreted. This is due to the fact that they are a couple of hundred years removed from the environment of the text which they investigate and are not fully familiar with the habits and customs of, say, an Egyptian scribe of rural documents in the 9th century or with the layout of petitions from the Mamlūk period. The more information scholars can collect of these customs and habits the more securely can they interpret those texts, i.e. the more one knowns about the context the easier can one read the text.

The point with the *hamzat al-waṣl* or *alif al-waṣl* is not so much how it is pronounced but how that which precedes it is pronounced. In fact the *alif al-waṣl* is in most cases not pronounced at all -- not even with a an "a" (a *fatḥa*).
The article in Arabic is *al-* and consists of an *alif al-waṣl* and the letter *lām*. In an isolated form, you say "***a**l-kitāb*", for example, or "***a**l-qurʾān*" with an "a", because the letter *alif* is pronounced as an "a".
The *alif al-waṣl*, however, is simply not pronounced at all when it is preceded by a vowel from another word. In your example from al-Fātiḥa, you find the following:
> ٱهۡدِنَا ٱلصِّرَٰطَ ٱلۡمُسۡتَقِيمَ
What you read, however, is the following:
> ihdinā ṣ-ṣirāṭa l-mustaqīma
In other words, you do not read the *alif* of the article but merley the long "ā" of the pronoun attached to the preceding verb (in the case of ṣ-ṣirāṭa) and the "a" of the preceding noun (in the case of l-mustaqīma).
Another example:
> باب البيت : bābu l-bayti ("the door of the house")
Here again, the *alif* is not pronounced, but you pronounce the "u" of the preceding noun (due to its being in the nominative).
Another example:
> باب البيت الكبير : bābu l-bayti l-kabīri ("the door of the large house")
Here again, the *alif* of the word for "house" is not pronounced, but you pronounce the "u" of the preceding noun, whereas the *alif* of the adjective "large" is not pronounced and takes over the "i" of the preceding noun (due to the genitive of "house").
The article is not the only instance of an *alif al-waṣl*. Verbs like *infaʿala* ("to be done, to be affected") or nouns like *ism* ("name") and *ibn* ("son") have it, too.

Update:
Since you are asking particularly about how to pronounce the *alif al-waṣl* **at the beginning of speech** (which I only now came to understand), let me add the following.
In your example from al-Fātiḥā, the word in question (*ihdinā*) is an imperative, which is always pronounced as an "i". So, in that case, you simply have to know that the *alif al-waṣl* of imperatives is an "i".
There are, however, some imperatives which take "u", like *uḫruǧ* ("get out!"). This is something that needs to be learned, I am afraid.

Since you are asking particularly about how to pronounce the *alif al-waṣl* **at the beginning of speech** (which I only now came to understand), let me add the following:
- In your example from al-Fātiḥā, the word in question (*ihdinā*) is an imperative. Most imperatives are pronounced as an "i". So, in that case, you simply have to know that the *alif al-waṣl* of the imperative of *hadā* (to lead") is an "i". There are, however, some imperatives which take "u", like *uḫruǧ* ("get out!").
- Verbs whose present tense contain a "u" take the *alif al-waṣl* of the imperative as "u". - Verbs whose present tense contain a "i" or "a" take the *alif al-waṣl* of the imperative as "i".
- As for the perfect tense of verbs: if they have an *alif al-waṣl*, they always take "i" (as *infaʿāla*).
- As for nouns, they also usually take "i" (as *ibn*).
- Loanwords from other languages (e.g. Greek) sometimes take "a" (*aflāṭūn*) or "u" (* usṭuquss*).
---
Generally, the point with the *hamzat al-waṣl* or *alif al-waṣl* is not so much how it is pronounced but how that which precedes it is pronounced. In fact the *alif al-waṣl* is in most cases not pronounced at all -- not even with a an "a" (a *fatḥa*).
The article in Arabic is *al-* and consists of an *alif al-waṣl* and the letter *lām*. In an isolated form, you say "***a**l-kitāb*", for example, or "***a**l-qurʾān*" with an "a", because the letter *alif* is pronounced as an "a".
The *alif al-waṣl*, however, is simply not pronounced at all when it is preceded by a vowel from another word. In your example from al-Fātiḥa, you find the following:
> ٱهۡدِنَا ٱلصِّرَٰطَ ٱلۡمُسۡتَقِيمَ
What you read, however, is the following:
> ihdinā ṣ-ṣirāṭa l-mustaqīma
In other words, you do not read the *alif* of the article but merley the long "ā" of the pronoun attached to the preceding verb (in the case of ṣ-ṣirāṭa) and the "a" of the preceding noun (in the case of l-mustaqīma).
Another example:
> باب البيت : bābu l-bayti ("the door of the house")
Here again, the *alif* is not pronounced, but you pronounce the "u" of the preceding noun (due to its being in the nominative).
Another example:
> باب البيت الكبير : bābu l-bayti l-kabīri ("the door of the large house")
Here again, the *alif* of the word for "house" is not pronounced, but you pronounce the "u" of the preceding noun, whereas the *alif* of the adjective "large" is not pronounced and takes over the "i" of the preceding noun (due to the genitive of "house").
The article is not the only instance of an *alif al-waṣl*. Verbs like *infaʿala* ("to be done, to be affected") or nouns like *ism* ("name") and *ibn* ("son") have it, too.

**عربي** :
رُفِعَ "قبلُ" بناءا في محل الجر، و البناء اتى لتجرد الاسم "قبلُ" من الاضافة، الاصل او السهل المتبادر للذهن، هو ان يتبع الاسم "قبلُ" بمضاف اليه فيجر كما هو معتاد عليه،
كقوله تعالى : "وَلَوْ شَاءَ اللَّهُ مَا اقْتَتَلَ الَّذِينَ `مِنْ بَعْدِهِمْ` `مِنْ بَعْدِ مَا جَاءَتْهُمُ` الْبَيِّنَاتُ".
لاحظ جر كلمة "بعدِ" مرتين، المرة الاولى في "بَعْدِهِمْ" اذ اتت مضافا و الضمير المتصل "ه" في محل جر المضاف اليه، و المرة الثانية في "بَعْدِ مَا جَاءَتْهُمُ" اذ اتت مضافا و الجملة الفعلية "مَا جَاءَتْهُمُ" مضاف اليه، اذا الحكمة في الاضافة، ان كان الاسم مضافا و ارتبط بمضاف اليه كان مجرورا، و ان تجرد من الاضافة كان مبنيا على الضم في محل جر.
**English**
The word "قبلُ" came with a "ُ " instead of a "ِ " because it didn't came in the state of `Moudhaf` "مضاف" and because it wasn't tied with a `Moudhaf ilayh` "مضاف اليه", if it was so, it would come with a `Kasrah` "ِ " as it is in the verse :
"وَلَوْ شَاءَ اللَّهُ مَا اقْتَتَلَ الَّذِينَ `مِنْ بَعْدِهِمْ` `مِنْ بَعْدِ مَا جَاءَتْهُمُ` الْبَيِّنَاتُ".

There are 3 patterns to build plural in arabic : 1-جمع مذكر سالم ( the non broken male plural) which we construct by just adding ون or ين at the end of the male noun without breaking the initial singular word for example : معلم =teacher(male) معلمون =teachers معلمين= teachers (ين) or (ون) depends on the position of the noun in a sentence 2. جمع مؤنث سالم (the non broken female plural) same as 1 , used just for female name by adding ات at the end without breaking the initial singular word for example : مغنية =singer ( female) مغنيات =singers (as u see we removed the ة and we replaced it by ات to construct the plural 3. جمع تكسير (breaking plural) we break the initial singular by adding letters in the middle and the beginning to make the plural , like the examples that u gave in your question , unfortunately there is no rule for this pattern , you should know the noun and its plural by heart

When words end with double-tanween (un/an/in), that affects the grammar of the word, not the meaning. There are a number of things that can cause words to take one of these three cases (which they must), and this is essentially the study of grammar.
Some simple examples (with other vowel marks omitted):
- هاذا مسجدٌ: this is a masjid (masjid*un*) - رأيت مسجدًا: I saw a masjid (masjid*an*) - هو في مسجدٍ: He is in the masjid (masjid*in*)
The meaning of the word (masjid) didn't change, but the ending sound does.
This only applies to nouns. It doesn't apply universally, eg. some plurals (like masculine/feminine plurals) don't follow this pattern.
I would suggest `إفرنقع!` or `أغرب عن وجهي!` with the meaning `Go Away!`/`Get out of my face!`.

The core meaning of the word does not change. The word "يوم" will mean "day" in all sentences. However, the vocalization serves to indicate the position of the word and, in a sense, changes the contextual meaning of the word.
* In your first sentence the word "يوم" is the subject of this sentence. * In the second sentence, the focus is on the action of those addressed in this sentence (the believers) on that day. * In the third sentence the word "يوم" can be considered a marginal addition to the sentence.

These are normally considered "short vowel marks" and are used (normally) for indefinite nouns, for example saying a Mosque would be Dammatain in defacto persona in most cases however saying "the Mosque" would actually be a damma in defacto persona.
For example:
> هاذا المسجدُ
"This is the Mosque", which ends in a Damma.
> هاذا مسجدٌ
"This is a Mosque", which ends in a Dammatain
It is good to note that the Alif on the end actually means something else again and can normally be used for direct objects (though it has other rules too). An example of a word that uses a Alif ending is:
> مرحباً
"Marhaban"
Which in this case is because of a particular rule in relation to the "a" ending on Marhaba.
But that is a much wider topic which involves the talking about how direct objects are used in relation to certain verbs etc etc (i.e. with use of "kam" meaning how much/many) and in certain phrases etc etc.

إِضْطُرٓ يَضْطَرُ
Maybe because of the _sokoon_ over ض, it's not as obvious as the ط. Although it's slightly pronounced.

Moreover, in the holy Quran it's different, in some verses, letters aren't pronounced or replaced with similar _phonic_ letters.
These rules are called _Tajweed_, such as إِقلاب and إخفاء.
Example for إخفاء لاَ انفِصٓام لها Here the ن is silent.
Example for إقلاب أنْ بُوُرِكٓ
The ن is silent and replaced with ب

> I have heard that one of the easy things about it is that you spell what you pronounce, are there any exceptions?
Not at all, take a Hamza Tul wasl for example waalmasjidu (and the Mosque) is actually said as walmasjidu.
So this rule is not true and you regularly say different to what you write.
Another perfect example is solar letters: ashshamsu (the sun) is actually witten as al-shamsu
So get this rule out of your head, it is not in a single bit true.
As for silent letters: I too have not encountered any, merging of letters is slightly different to silent letters and much easier to work around.

I always thought it should be اللغة العربية or لغة العرب.
This would also follow the pattern of another word: لغة القرآن which would become اللغة القرآنية.
Any definite explanation?

You can't say "لغة العربية" because "العربية" is an adjective (صفة), it cant be مضاف and مضاف إليه. It can be موصوف and صفة.
It's not the same of لغة القرآن.

You can't say "لغة العربية" because "العربية" is an adjective (صفة), it cant be مضاف and مضاف إليه. It can be موصوف and صفة.
It's not the same of لغة القرآن. "القرآن" is not an adjective.

You can't say "لغة العربية" because "العربية" is an adjective (صفة), it can't be مضاف and مضاف إليه. It can be موصوف and صفة.
It's not the same of لغة القرآن. Quran (القرآن) is not an adjective.

This is adding a word to another one .. for example you can add your hand to yourself .. we can say يدك means your hand, you can say لغتي my language also لغة الكتاب the language of the book ..

It is true that in historical textual witnesses many words, indeed most of them, were often written without dots (or wer only incompletely equipped with dots). In fact, some manuscripts are (almost entirely) devoid of dots at all. What we get in these manuscripts and teastimonies is the bare *rasm*, i.e., the skeleton of the word, like كىٮ , which could be *kuntu* or *kataba*, and so on. In many cases this will be no problem for a learned scribe or reader, as the context will usually provide enough pieces of information for what the word could (or should) be.
This being said, it is clear that there is a certain (sometimes high) degree of ambiguity that arises from missing dots. So, scribes often added at least some dots (but not all of them) to disambiguate more sufficiently.
Nowadays, scholars working with historical texts nonetheless have a lot to do in finding out how the dotless words should properly be interpreted. This is due to the fact that they are a couple of hundred years removed from the environment of the text which they investigate and are not fully familiar with the habits and customs of, say, an Egyptian scribe of rural documents in the 9th century or with the layout of petitions from the Mamlūk period. The more information scholars can collect of these customs and habits the more securely can they interpret those texts, i.e. the more one knowns about the context the easier can one read the text.
Other than that, it should be added that even with all dots supplied, there are ambiguous cases, as some word patters are identical, e.g. the active or passive voice of most participles (*mufaʿʿil* vs. *mufaʿʿal*), or a imperfect verb in the the first stem (*yafʿalu*) could also be a verb in the second stem (*yufaʿʿilu*) or fourth stem (*yufʿilu*). Nowadays we tend to add vowel-signs but these were even more absent from most historical (especially non-religious) texts than dots.

This is called *[Pangram][1]* / *[جامع حروف][2]*. Here is examples of poetry:
1. صف خلق خود كمثل الشمس إذ بزغت *** يحظى الضجيع بها نجلاء معطار 3. هلا سكنت بذي ضغث فقد زعموا *** شخصت تطلب ظبيا راح مجتازا 2. اصبر على حفظ خضر واستشر فطنا *** وزج همك (قريب) بغداذ منثملا

This being said, it is clear that there is a certain (sometimes even high) degree of ambiguity that arises from missing dots. So, scribes often added at least some dots (but not all of them) to disambiguate more sufficiently.

Nowadays, scholars working with historical texts nonetheless have a lot to do in finding out how the dotless words should properly be interpreted. This is due to the fact that they are a couple of hundred years removed from the environment of the text which they investigate and are not fully familiar with the habits and customs of, say, an Egyptian scribe of rural documents in the 9th century or with the layout of petitions from the Mamlūk period. The more information scholars can collect of these customs and habits the more securely can they interpret those texts, i.e. the more one knows about the context the easier can one read the text.

The word **امرأة** is singular and it means woman (singular), and the plural form of it is the word **نساء**.
There's, however, not "primary" word, since there are usually many synonyms for any word in Arabic. However, the easy, common word for women is **نساء**.

According to *A Reference Grammar of Modern Standard Arabic* (Karin Ryding, 2005), Chapter 11 section 4.1.3:
> The word *baʿdu*, with the *Damma* inflection and no nunation, acts as an adverb in negative clauses to mean ‘not...yet,’ ‘still ... not.’ When inflected with the *Damma*, it cannot be the first term of a genitive construct.<sup>12</sup>
This doesn't answer the question, but the footnote is very interesting:
> <sup>12</sup>The *Damma* is not thought to represent the nominative case here but is rather an archaic form of Semitic locative “un ancien cas adverbial en *-u* qui n'est pas le nominatif” (Lecomte 1968, 90). Similar forms such as *qabl-u* ‘before’, *fawq-u* ‘above,’ and *taHt-u* ‘beneath’ also exist, with the restriction that they may not occur as the first term of an *ʾiDaafa*. On this topic see also Fleisch 1961, I:280, and Chapter 16, section 3.4.3.
Following up the reference to Chapter 16, there is another interesting footnote:
> <sup>13</sup> The final *Damma* on *baʿd-u* and on certain other semi-prepositions (*qabl-u*, *taHt-u*) is considered to be a remnant of an old locative case. This *Damma* has two characteristics: (1) it is invariable, even after a preposition (e.g., *min qabl-u*; *min taHt-u*); (2) it cannot be on the first term of an *ʾiDaafa*, that is, it cannot be followed by a noun in the genitive case or by a pronoun suffix. See chapter 11, section 4.1.3, especially note 12.
This suggests that the *-u* ending is a remnant of what used to be another case in proto-Semitic, but by Qur'anic times was only visible in a few words that behave differently to what you expect.
If you want to follow up those references, they are:
* Lecomte, Gerard. 1968. *Grammaire de l'arabe*. Paris: Presses Universitaires de France. * Fleisch, Henri. 1961, 1979. *Traité de philologie arabe I et II*. 2 vols. Beirut: Imprimerie Catholique 1961 (vol I); Beirut: Dar al-Machreq 1979 (vol. II)

I know that there may be more complex sentences that you can't get easily but they used to know.
And what I found is that this is the same in some other languages such as in English. One word can have many meanings as a word but only in a sentence context you can get the correct meaning.
And to imagine how good they were in Arabic, the entire Quran was written without dots at the beginning, and everyone understood it very well without mistakes.
Also in the age of ancient Arabians, books were rare and they used memories to remember poems for example.

row.Text:
**أوزان جموع التكسير**
جمع التكسير هو ما دلَّ على أكثر من اثنين بتغيير صورة مفرده، تغييرًا مقدرًا كفُلْك، بضم فسكون، للمفرد والْجمع، فزنته فى المفرد كزنة قُفْل، وفى الجمع كزنة أسْد، وكهِجان لنوع من الإبل، ففى المفرد ككتاب، وفى الجمع كرِجال.
أو تغييرًا ظاهرًا، إما بالشكل فقط، كأُسْد بضم فسكون، جمع أسدَ بفتحتين. وإما بالزيادة فقط، كصِنوان، فى جمع صِنو بكسر فسكون فيهما. وإما بالنقص فقط، كتُخَم فى جمع تُخَمة بضم ففتح فيهما. وإما بالشكل والزيادة كرِجال بالكسر، فى جمع رَجل بفتح فضم. وإما بالشكل والنقص كَكُتب بضمتين. فى جمع كتاب بالكسر. وإما بالثلاثة، كغِلمان بكسر فسكون، فى جمع غلام بالضم.
وهذا الجمع عامًّ فى العقلاء وغيرهم، ذكورًا كانوا أو إناثًا. وأبنيته سبعة وعشرون، منها أربعة للقِلة، والباقى للكثرة.
فالقلة: من ثلاثة إلى عشرة، والكثرة: من أحد عشر إلى ما لا نهاية له. وقيل: إنهما متفقان مبدأ لا غاية، فالقلة: من ثلاثة إلى عشرة. والكثرة: من ثلاثة إلى ما لا نهاية له. وإنما تعتبر القلة فى نكرات الْجموع، أما معارفها بأل أو الإضافة فصالحة للقلة والكثرة، باعتبار الجنس أو الاستغراق، وقد ينوب أحدهما عن الآخر وضعًا: بأن تضع العرب أحد البناءين صالحًا للقلة والكثرة، ويستغنون به عن وضع الآخر، فيستعمَل مكانه بالاشتراك المعنوىّ لا مجازًا
ولكل من النوعين السابقين أوزان وقواعد ، حرص الصرفيون جاهدين العمل بها ، والتقيد بضوابطها ، ولكن مما تجدر الإشارة إليه قبل الخوض في أنواع وصيغ جموع التكسير ، أن نذكر أنّ هذه الجموع منها السماعي الذي لا بد من الرجوع لمعرفته إلى معاجم اللغة ، وكتب النحو للوقوف عليها ، ومنها القياسي الذي وضعت له القواعد والأوزان تطبق على كل ما توافرت فيه الشروط عند الجمع .
---
**أولا : جموع الكثرة .**
1. **فُعْل، بضم فسكون:**
وينقاس فى أفْعَلَ ومُؤنّثِه فَعْلاء صِفتين، كحُمْر بضم فسكون، فى جمع أحمر وحمراء. ويكثر فى الشعر ضم عينه إن صحت هى ولامه ولم يضعَّف، نحو: *وَأنْكَرَتْنِى ذَوَاتُ الأعْيُنِ النُّجُلِ* بضم الجيم جمع نَجْلاء: أى واسعة، بخلاف نحو بيضٍ وَعُمْى وغُرّ فلا يُضَم لاعتلال العين فى الأول، واللام فى الثانى، والتضعيف فى الثالث. وكما يكون جمعًا لأفْعَل الذى مؤنثه فَعْلاء، يكون جمعًا أيضًا لأفعل الذى لا مؤنث له أصلاً، كأكْمَر لعظيم الكَمَرَة، وكذا لفَعلاء الذى لا أفعل له كَرَتْقاء.
2. **فُعُل، بضمتين:**
ويطَّرد فى وصف على فَعُول بمعنى فاعل، كغفور وغُفُر، وصَبور وصُبُر. وفى كل اسم رُباعىّ قبل آخره مدّ، صحيح الآخِر، مذكرًا، كان أو مؤنثًا، كقَذَال بالفتح، وجمع جِمَاع مؤخَّر الرأس، وقُذُل، وحِمار وَحُمُر، وكُرَاع بالضم وكُرُع، وقضيب وقُضُب، وَعمود وعُمُد. ويشترط فى مفرده أيضًا ألاّ يكون مضعَّفًا مَدّته ألف. ثم إن كانت عين هذا الْجمع واوًا وجب تسكينُها، كَسُوْر وسُوْك جمعَىْ سِوار وسِواك، وإلا جاز ضمها وتسكينها، نحو قُذُل بضمتين، وقُذْل بالسكون، وسُيُل بضمتين، وسِيْل بكسر فسكون، جمع سَيال: اسم شجر له شوك، لكن إن سكنت الياء وجب كسر ما قبلها، نظير بِيْض فى جمع أبيض.
3. **فُعَل بضم ففتح:**
ويطرد فى اسم على فُعْلة بضم فسكون، وفى فُعْلى بضم فسكون أنثى أفعل، كغُرْفة ومُدْية وحُجّة. وكصُغْرَى، وكُبْرَى، فتقول فيها: غُرَف، ومُدًى، وحُجَج، وصُغَر وكُبَر. وشذَّ فى بُهْمة بضم فسكون، وصف للرجل الشجاع: بُهَم، كما شذ جمع رُؤْيا بضم الأوَّل، ونَوْبة وقَرْية بفتح أوَّلهما، ولِحْيَة بكسره، وتُخَمة بضم ففتح، على فُعَل، للمصدرية فى الأوَّل، وانتفاء ضم الفاء فى الثلاثة بعده، وفتح عين الأخير.
4. **فِعَل، بكسر ففتح:**
ويطَّرد فى اسمٍ على فِعْلة بكسر فسكون، كحِجَّة وحِجج، وكِسْرة وكِسَر، وفِرْية، وهى الكذب، وفِرًى. وسُمِع فى حِلية ولِحْيَة بكسر أوَّلهما: حُلىً وَلُحًى بضمه، كما سمع فى فُعْلة بضم فسكون: فِعَل بكسر ففتح، كصُورة وصِوَر.
5. **فُعَلَة، بضم ففتح:**
ويطَّرد فى وصفِ عاقلٍ على وزن فاعل معتل اللام، كقاضٍ وقضاة، وَرَامٍ ورُماة، وغاز وغُزَاة.
6. **فَعَلة، بفتحات:**
ويطَّرد فى وصف مذكر عاقل صحيح اللام ككاتب وكَتَبة، وساحر وسَحَرة، وبائع وباعة، وصائغ وصاغَة، وبارٍّ وبَرَرة، وبعضهم يجعل هذه الصيغة أصل سابقتها، وإنما ضُمّت فاء الأولى، للفرق بين صحيح اللام ومعتلها.
7. **فَعْلَى، بفتح فسكون ففتح:**
ويطَّرد فى وصفٍ دالٍّ على هلاك، أو توجُّع، أو تشتُّت، بزنة فَعِيل، نحو قتيل وقَتْلَى، وجريح وجَرْحَى، وأسير وأسْرَى، ومريض ومَرْضَى. أو زنة فَعِل بفتح فكسر، كزَمِن وزَمْنَى، أو زنة فاعل، كهالك وهَلْكَى، أو زنة فَيْعِل بفتح فسكون فكسر، كميت ومَوْتَى، أو زنة أفعَل كأحمَقَ وَحَمْقى، أو زنة فَعْلان، كعطشان وعَطْشَى.
8. **فِعَلَة، بكسر ففتح:**
وهو كثير فى فُعْل بضم فسكون اسمًا صحيح اللام، كقُرْط وقِرَطة، ودُرْج ودِرَجة، وكُوز وكِوَزة، ودُبّ ودِبَبة. وقلَّ فى اسم صحيح اللام على فَعْل بفتح فسكون: كغَرْد (بالغين المعجمة لنوع من الكمأة) وغِرَدَة، أو بكسر فسكون: كقِرْد وقِرَدة.
9. **فُعَّل، بضم الأول، وتشديد الثانى مفتوحًا:**
ويطَّرد فى وصف على وزن فاعل وفاعلة صحيحَىْ اللام، كراكع وراكعة، وصائم وصائمة، تقول فى الجمع: رُكَّع وصُوَّم. وندر فى معتلها كغازٍ وغُزَّى، كما ندر فى فَعيلة وفُعَلاء بضم ففتح، كخَريدة وخُرَّد، ونُفَسَاء ونفَّس.
10. **فُعَّال، بضم الأول، وفتح الثانى مشدَّدًا.**
ويطَّرد كسابقه فى وصف على فاعل، فيقال: صائم وصوَّام، وقارئ وقرَّاء، وعاذل وعُذَّال، وندر فى وصف على فاعلة، كصُدَّاد فى قول القُطامىّ: *أبْصَارُهُنَّ إلى الشُّبَّانِ مائلةٌ * وقد أَراهُنَّ عنى غيْرَ صُدَّادِ* كما ندر فى المعتل، كغازٍ وغُزَّاء، وسارٍ وسُرَّاء.
11. **فِعَال، بكسر ففتح مخففا: ويطَّرد فى ثمانية أنواع:**
الأول والثانى: فَعْل وفَعْلة بفتح فسكون، اسمين أو وصفين، ليست عينهما ولا فاؤهما ياء، مثل كلْب وكلْبة وكِلاب، وصعْب وصَعْبة وصِعاب، وتُبدل واوُ المفرد ياء فى الجمع، كثَوْب وثِياب، وندر فيما عينه أو فاؤه الياء منهما، كضيْف وضِياف، ويَعْر ويِعار، وهو الجَدْى يُرْبط فى زُبْية الأسد.
الثالث والرابع: فَعَل وفَعَلة، بفتحتين اسمين صحيحى اللام، ليست عينهما ولامهما من جنس، نحو جَمَل وجِمال، ورَقَبة ورِقاب.
الخامس: فِعْل، بكسر فسكون اسمًا كقِدْح وَقِداح، وذِئْب وَذِئاب، ونِهْى، وهو الغدير، ونِهاء.
السادس: فُعْل، بضم فسكون اسمًا غير واوىِّ العين، ولا يائىّ اللام، كرُمْح ورِماح وجُبٍّ وجِباب.
السابع والثامن: فَعيل وفَعيلة، وَصْفىَ باب كَرُم، صحيحى اللام، كظريف وظريفة وَظِراف. وتلزم هذه الصغية فيما عينه واو من هذا النوع، فلا يُجْمع على غيرها، كطويل وطويلة وطِوال.
وشاعت أيضًا فى كل وصف على فَعْلان بفتح فسكون للمذكر، وفَعْلَى للمؤنث، وفُعلان بضم فسكون له وفُعْلانة لها، كغَضْبان وغَضْبَى وغِضاب، وعطْشان وعطْشَى وعِطاش، وكخُمْصان وخُمْصانة وخِماص.
12. **فُعُول، وبضمتين:**
ويطَّرد فى اسم على فَعِل، بفتح فكسر، ككَبِد وكُبُود، وَوَعِل ووُعُول، ونَمِر ونُمور. وفى فَعْل اسما ثلاثيًا ساكن العين، مثلث الفاء، نحو كَعْب وكعُوب، وَجُنْد وَجُنُود، وضِرْس وَضُرُوس. ويشترط أن لا تكون عين المفتوح أو المضموم واواً كحوض وحُوت، ولا لام المضموم ياء كمُدْى. وشَذّ فى نُؤْى: وهى الحفرة تُجعل حول الخباء، لوقايته من السيل نِئِىّ، ولا مضعفا كخُف. ويُحفظ فى فَعَل بفتحتين كأسَد وأسود، وذكَرَ وذُكور، وَشجَن، وهو الحزن، وشُجون.
13. **فِعْلان، بكسر فسكون:**
ويَطَّرد فى اسم على فُعالٍ بالضم، كغُراب وغِرْبان، وغُلاَم وغِلمان، أو فُعَل بضم ففتح كصُرَد وصِرْدان. وبه يُسْتَغْنَى عن أفعال فى جمع هذا المفرد. أو فُعْل بضم الفاء أو فتحها واوىّ العين الساكنة، كحُوت وَحِيتان، وكُوز وَكِيزان وتاج وَتِيجان، ونار وَنِيران. وَقلّ فى نحو: غَزَالِ غِزلان، وفى خروف خِرْفان، وفى نِسْوة نِسْوان.
14. **فُعْلان بضم فسكون.**
وَيكثر فى اسم على فَعْل بفتح فسكون، كظَهْر وَظهْران، وَبَطْن وَبُطْنان، أو على فَعَل بفتحتين صحيح العين وَليست هى ولامه من جنس واحد، كذكَر وذُكْران، وَحَمل بالمهملة، وهو ولد الضأن الصغير وحَمْلان، أو على فَعيل كقضيب وقُضْبان، وغَدِير وغُدْران. وقَلَّ فى نحو: راكب رُكْبان، وفى أسْود سُودَان.
15. **فُعَلاء، بضم ففتح ممدودًا.**
ويطَّرد فى وصف مذكر عاقل، على زنة فعيل بمعنى فاعل، غير مضعَّف ولا معتل اللام، ولا واوىّ العين، نحو كرِيم وكُرَماء، وبخيل وبُخلاء، وظريف وظُرَفاء. وشَذّ أسيرٌ وأسَرَاء، وقَتِيلٌ وُقتَلاء؛ لأنهما بمعنى مفعول. أو بمعنى مُفْعِل، بضم فسكون فكسر، كسميع بمعنى مُسْمِع، وأليم بمعنى مُؤْلم، تقول فيهما: سُمعاء وألَماء، أو بمعنى مُفاعِل، كخُلطاء وَجُلَساء، فى خَلِيط بمعنى مُخَالِط، وَجَلِيس بمعنى مجالِس: أو على زِنة فاعل دالاً على معنى كالغريزة، كصالح وصُلَحاء، وجاهِل وجُهَلاء. وشَذَّ: شُجَعاء فى شُجاع، وجُبناء فى جَبَان، وسُمَحاء فى سَمْح، وَخُلَفَاء فى خليفة؛ لأنها ليست على فَعِيل ولا فاعل.
16. **أفْعِلاء، بفتح فسكون فكسر:**
ويَطَّرد فى مُفْرد سابقه الأول، وهو فعيل، لكِنْ بشرط أن يكون معتلَّ اللام أو مضعفًا، كغنىّ وأغنياء، ونبىّ وأنبياء، وشديد وأشِدّاء، وعزيز وأعِزّاء، وهو لازم فيهما. وشذ فى نَصِيب أنْصِباء، وفى صديق أصْدقاء، وفى هَيِّن أَهْوِناء؛ لأنها ليست معتلة اللام ولا مضعفة.
17. **فَواعِل:**
ويطَّرد فى فاعِلةٍ اسمًا أو صِفة، كناصية ونواص، وكاذبة وكواذب، وفى اسم على فَوْعَل، بفتح فسكون ففتح، أوْ فَوْعَلة بفتح الأول والثالث وسكون ما بينهما. أو فاعِل بفتح العين أو كسرها، كجَوْهَر وجواهر، وصَوْمعة وصوامع، وخاتَم وخواتِم، وكاهِل وكواهل. أو فاعِل بكسر العين وصفًا لمؤنث، كحائض وحوائض، وحامل وحوامل؛ أو لمذكر غير عاقل كصاهلٍ وصواهل، وشاهقٍ وشواهق. وشذ فى فارسٍ: فوَارس، وفى ناكسٍ بمعنى خاضع: نَوَاكس، وفى هالِكٍ: هَوَالك. ويطرد أيضًا فى فاعِلاءَ، بكسر العين والمدّ، كقاصِعاءَ وَقَواصِع، ونافقاءَ ونَوَافق.
18. **فَعَائل، بالفتح وكسر ما بعد الألف:**
ويطرد فى رُباعىٍّ مؤنث، ثالثه مَدَّة، سواء كان تأنيثه بالتاء أو بالألف مطلقاً، أو بالمعنى، كسحابة وسحائب، ورسالة ورسائل، وصحيفة وصحائف، وذُؤابة وذوائب، وحَلوبة وحلائب، وشِمال بالكسر، وشَمال بالفتح: ريح تهب من جهة القطب الشمالىّ، وشَمائل، وَعجُوز وعَجائز، وسعيد علم امرأة وسعائد، وحَبَاَئر، وجَلُولاء: قرية بفارس، وجَلائل. ويُشْتَرَط فى ذى التاء من هذه الأمثلة: الاسميةُ، إلاَّ فَعيلة، فيشترط فيها ألا تكون بمعنى مفعولة، وشذ ذَبيحة وذبائح. وندر فى وَصِيد: وهو اسم للبيت أو فنائه: وَصَائد، وفى جزُور: جزائر، وفى سماء، اسم للمطر: سمائى.
19/20. **فَعَالِى، بفتح أوله وثانيه وكسر رابعه. فَعَالَى، بفتح أوله وثانيه ورابعه.**
وهاتان الصيغتان تشتركان فى أشياء، وينفرد كل منهما فى أشياء. فتشتركان فى فَعْلاء اسمًا كصَحْراء، أو صفة لا مذكر لها كعذراء، وفى ذى الألف المقصورة للتأنيث كحبلَى، أو الإلحاق، كذِفْرًى بكسر الأول: اسم للعظم الشاخص خلْف أذُن الناقة، وألفه للإلحاق بدرهم، وعَلْقًى بفتح الأول: اسم لنبت، فتقول فى جمعها صحارٍ وصحارَى، وعَذارٍ وعَذَارَى، وَحَبَالٍ وَحَبَالَى، وذَفارٍ وَذَفارَى، وعَلاقٍ وعَلاقَى. وتنفرد "الفَعالِى" بكسر اللام فى أشياء: منها فَعلاة بفتح فسكون، كمَوْماة: اسم للفلاة الواسعة التى لا نبات بها، وفِعْلاة بالكسر كسِعْلاة، اسم لأخبث الغِيلان، وفِعْلِية بكسرتين بينهما سكون مخفف الياء كهِبْرية، وهو ما يعلق بأصول الشَّعَر كنخالة الدقيق، أو ما يتطاير من زَغَب القُطْن والريش؛ وفَعْلُوة بفتح فسكون فضم كعَرقُوَة، اسم للخَشبَة المعترِضة فى فم الدلو، وما حذف أوّلُ زائديه كحبنطًى: اسم لعظيم البطن، وقَلَنْسُوة لما يُلْبَس على الرأس، وبُلَهْنِيَة، بضم ففتح فسكون فكسر: اسم لِسِعَة العيش، وحُبَارَى بضم الأول، تقول فى جمعها: مَوَامٍ، وسَنعَالٍ، وهَبَارٍ، وَعَرَاقٍ، وَحَبَاطٍ، وَقَلاَسٍ، وَبَلاهٍ، وَحَبارٍ. وينفرد "الفَعَالَى" بفتح اللام فى وصف على فَعْلان، كعطشانَ وغضْبان، أو على فَعْلَى بالفتح كعطْشَى وَغَضْبَى، تقول فى الجمع: عَطَاشَى وَغَضَابَى. والراجح فيهما ضم الفاء كسُكارى. ويحفظ المفتوح اللام فى نحو حَبِط بفتح فكسر وَحَبَاطَى، ويتيم ويَتَامَى وَأيِّم، وهى الخالية من الزوج وأيَامَى، وطاهِر وطَهَارَى، فى قول امرئ القيس: *ثيابُ بنى عَوْف طَهارَى نقِيَّةٌ* وفى شاةٍ رئيسٍ: إذا أصيب رأسها، ورآسَى. ويُحفظ المضموم فى نحو قديم وقُدَامى، وأسير وأسارَى.
21. **فَعَالِىّ، بفتحتين وكسر اللام وتشديد الياء:**
ويطرد فى كل ثلاثى ساكن العين، زيد فى آخره ياء مشدَّدة، ليست متجدَّدة للنسب، ككُرسىِّ وبُخْتىّ وَقُمْرِىّ، بالضم، أو لنسب تُنُوسِىَ كَمَهْرِىّ، تقول فى جمعها: كراسِىّ، وَبَخاتِىّ، وقمَارِىّ، وَمَهَارِىّ. والفرق أن ياء النسب يدل اللفظ بعد حذفها على معنى بخلاف ياء نحو كرسىّ، إذ يختل اللفظ بعد سقوطه ولا يكون له معنى، وشذّ قَبَاطِىّ فى قُِبطىّ لأن ياءه للنسب، والقِبط: نصارَى مصر. ويُحْفَظ فى إنسان، وَظربان بفتح فكسر، إذ قد سمع أناسىُّ وَظَرَابىُّ، وليسا جمعًا لإنسىٍّ وَظِرْبىّ بل أصلهما: أناسينُ وضرابينُ، قلبت النون فيهما ياء، وأدغمت الياء فى الياء. وَسُمِع فى عَذْراء وَصحْراء تقول فيهما: عذَارِىُّ وَصَحَارِىّ.
22. **فَعَالِلُ:**
ويطرد فى الرُّباعِىّ المجرَّد ومزيده، وكذا فى الْخماسىّ المجرّد ومزيده، فتقول فى جعْفَر وبُرْثُن وَزبْرِج: جعافِر، وَبَرَاثِن، وزَبارِج. أما الخماسىّ فإن لم يكن رابعه يشبه الزائد، حُذِف الخامس كسَفَرْجل، تقول فيه: سَفَارِج، وإن أشبه الزائد فى اللفظ أو المخرَج فأنت بالخيار بين حذفه وحذف الخامس، فتقول فى نحو خَدَرْنَق بوزن سفَرْجل، اسم للعنكبوت، وفى فرزدق بوزنه أيضًا: خَدَارِقُ أو خَدَارِنُ، وفَرَازِقُ أو فرازدُ؛ إذ النون فى الأول من حروف الزيادة، والدال فى الثانى تشبه التاء فى المخرج، وتقول فى مزيد الرُّباعِىّ نحو مُدَحْرِج: دَحارِج بحذف الزائد، إلا إذا كان ما قبل الآخر لِينا فلا يُحْذَف، ثم إن كان اللين ياءً صحّ، كقنديل وقناديل، وإن كان ألفا أو واوًا قلب ياء نحو سِرْداح، وهى الناقة الشديدة، وعصفور، فتقول فيهما: سراديح وعصافير، وفى مزيد الخماسى: يحذف الخامس مع الزائد، فتقول فى قِرْطَبُوس بكسر القاف: للناقة الشديدة، وبالفتح: للداهية، وَقَبَعْثَرًى: قراطِب وقباعِث.
23. **شِبْه فَعَالِل**
وهو ما ماثله عَدَدًا وهيئة، وإن خالفه زِنة، وذلك كمفاعِل، وفوَاعِل، وفياعِل، وأفاعِلة.
ويطرّد فى مزيد الثلاثى غير ما تقدم من نحو أحمر، وسكران، وصائم، ورام، وباب كُبْرَى وَسَكْرَى، فإن لها جموعَ تكسير تقدمت ولا يُحْذَف الزائد إن كان واحدًا، كأفضلَ ومَسْجدٍ وَجَوْهَرٍ وَصَيْرَفٍ وَعَلْقى، بل يُحذَف ما زاد عليه، سواء كان واحدًا كما فى نحو منطلق، أو اثنين كما فى نحو مستخرج، ويُؤْثَر بالبقاء ما له مزِيَّة على الآخر، معنىً ولفظاً كالميم، فيقال: مَطالِق وَمَخارج، لا نَطَالق وسَخَارِج أو تَخَارِج، لفضْل الميم، بتصدّرها، ودلالتها على معنى يختص بالأسماء؛ لأنها تدلُّ على اسمَىْ الفاعل والمفعول، وكالهمزة والياء مصدَّرتين فى نحو ألنَدد وَيَلَنْدَد للشديد الخصومة؛ لأنهما فى موضعين يقعان فيه دالّين على معنى كأقوم ويقوم، فتقول فى جمعها: ألاَدُّ وَيَلاَدُّ، أو لفظًا فقط: كالتاء فى نحو استخراج، تقول فى جمعه: تَخَارِيج بإبقاء التاء؛ لأنها لا تُخْرِج الكلمة عن عدم النظير، بل لها نظير نحو تَبَاريح وتماثيل وتصاوير، بخلاف السين لو قلت سَخَاريج، إذ لا وجود لسفاعيل. وكالواو فى نحو حَيْزَبُون للعجوز، فإن بقاءها يغنى عن حذف غيرها، وهو الياء، فتقول فى جمعه: حَزَابِين، بقلب الواو ياءً كما فى عُصْفور، بخلاف ما لو حذفتها وأبقيت الياء، وقلت: حَيَازِبْن بسكون الموحدة قبل النون، فإن حذفها لا يغنى عن حذف غيرها، إذ لا يلى ألف التكسير ثلاث إلا وأوسطهن ساكن معتلّ. فيلجئك ذلك إلى حذف المثناة التحتية، حتى يحصل مفاعل، فتقول: حَزَابِن. فإن لم يكن لأحد الزائدَين مزية على الآخرَ. فأنت بالخيار فى حذف أيهما شئت، كنونَىْ: سَرَنْدَى: للسريع فى أموره والشديد. وعَلَنْدَى للغليظ وألفيهما. فتقول: سرانِد، وعلاند بحذف الألف، وسراد وعلادٍ بحذف النون. وكذا حَبَنْطَى لعظيم البطن. تقول فيه: حَبانِطٍ وَحَبَاطٍ، بقلب الألف ياءً، ثم يُعَلّ إعلال جَوَارٍ؛ لأن كلتا الزيادتين للإلحاق بسفرجل؛ فتكافأتا. فلننتبه إلى أن فعاليل ليست شبه فعالل ، ( كما يظن لبعضنا ) بل من فعالل ، خماسي قبل آخره حرف مد فعند جمعه يقلب ياء ، نحو " عصفور " " عصافير "

**ثانيا : جموع القِلَّة**
1. **أفْعُل، بفتح فسكون فضم**
: ويطرَّد فى:
1- كل اسم ثلاثى صحيح الفاء والعين ولم يضاعَف، على وزن فَعْل، بفتح فسكون، ككلْب وأكْلُب، وظَبْى وأظْبٍ، ودَلْو وأَدْلٍ. وما كان من هذا النوع واوىَّ اللام أو يائيها، تكسر عينه فى الجمع، وتحذف لامه، كما سيأتى: فى الإعلال. وشذ: أوْجُه، وأكُفّ، وأعْيُن.وأثْوُب، وأسْيُف فى قوله: *لكُل دَهَرٍ قد لَبِسْتُ أثْوُبا * حتَّى اكْتَسَى الرَّأْسُ قناَعاً أشْهَبَا* وقوله: *كأنَّهُمْ أسْيُفٌ بِيضٌ يَمَانِيَةٌ * عضْبٌ مَضَارِبُها باقٍ بهَا الأثُرُ*
2- وفى اسم رباعىّ مؤنّث بلا علامة، قبل آخره مدّ، كذراع وأذرع، ويمين وأيمن، وشذ أفْعُلٌ فى مكانٍ، وغُرابٍ، وشهابٍ، من المذكر.
2. **أفْعَال، بفتح فسكون.**
ويكون جمعًا لكل ما لم يَطرَّد فيه أفْعُلٌ السابق، كثوب وأثواب، وسيف وأسياف، وحِمْل بكسر فسكون وأحمال، وصُلْب بضم فسكون وأصلاب، وباب وأبواب، وسبَب بفتحتين وأسباب، وكَتِف بفتح فكسر وأكتاف، وعَضُد بفتح فضم وأعضاد، وجُنُب بضمتين وأجناب، ورُطَب بضم ففتح وأرطاب، وإبِل بكسرتين وآبال، وضِلَع بكسرٍ ففتح وأضلاع، وشذ أفراخ فى قول الحُطيئة: *ماذا تقولُ لأفرَاخٍ بذى مَرَخٍ * زُغْبِ الحواصلِ لا ماءٌ ولا شجَرُ* كما شذّ أحمال جمع حَمْل، بفتح فسكون، فى قوله تعالى: {وَأولاتُ الأحْمَالِ أجَلُهُنَّ أنْ يَضَعْنَ حَمْلَهُنَّ}.
3. **أفْعِلَة، بفتح فسكون فكسر.**
ويطرِّد فى كل اسم مذكرَّ رُباعىّ قبل آخره مدّ، كطعام وأطعمة، ورغيف وأرغفة، وعمود وأعمدة، وَيُلْتزَم فى فِعَالٍ، بفتح أوله أو كسره، مضعَّف اللام أو معتلها، كَبَتَاتٍ وأبِتَّة، وزِمام وأَزِمَّة، وقِباء وأقبية، وكِساء وأكِسية، ولا يُجمعان على غيره إلا شذوذًا.
4. **فِعْلة، بكسر فسكون.**
ولم يطرِّد فى شئ، بل سمع فى ألفاظ، منها شِيخة جمع شيخ، وثِيْرة جمع ثوْر، وفِتية جمع فَتًى، وصِبْية جمع صَبِىّ وَصَبِيّة، وغِلْمة جمع غُلام، و ثِنْية جمع ثُنْىِ بضم الأول أو كسره، وهو الثانى فى السيادة.
ولعدم اطراده قيل إنه اسم جمع لا جمع.

The five nouns are:
1. أبُو (Father) 2. أَخُو (Brother) 3. حَمُو (Father in law) 4. فُو (Mouth) 5. ذُو (Owner of)
The five nouns are excluded from the other single nouns according to the syntactic case. They have other marks to indicate them syntactic cases that the other doesn't have. The single noun always depends on rules in order to indicate its syntactic cases but the five nouns are contradicting those rules: ![enter image description here][1]
There is a sixth one `هنو` but its debatable because it's not commonly used in this form but as `هن` with ordinary syntactic cases.
[1]: http://i.stack.imgur.com/PE57k.png

> أب father > > اخ brother > > حم brother in law > > فو mouth > > ذو with
The are special as they have irregular forms other Arabic knows don't have. The spelling of each of them changes based on the parsing `الاعراب`
There is a similar sixth one
> هنو Genitals
The myth says that Arabs don't mention it because of it's sexual nature, the truth is that it's unlike the other five can come in regular form.

If someone said لغة nobody would understand which language are you referring to! Another example if someone said وجه (or face) ! Which face do you mean? he must determine what he is saying
The words like لغة or وجه are "a common part" of many things i.e. the لغة may be English, French etc. and the وجه may be the face of a bird or the face of a human etc.
If you said وجه الإنسان (or the face of the human) then by adding the word الإنسان you made it clear and this part (الإنسان) by adding the face to it we understand that the face belongs to the human and this made the sentence defined and clear so, you can add the language to the people you may say لغة العرب the language of the arab people.
This is adding a word to another one, for example you can add your hand to yourself so we can say يدك means your hand, you can say لغتي my language also لغة الكتاب the language of the book.
Another thing is to describe something to be with a particular attribute like saying يد رفيعة means a thin hand also you may describe your tongue to be arabic if you speak arabic لسان عربي means arabic tongue
So, the point is there is:

But لغة العربية is like you have deleted something from the sentence (and this is alright you can delete it so it's grammatically correct) the sentence without deleting anything is لغة اللغة العربية which means the language of the arabic language! it may be like a clue! what's the language of this language? or another example وجه الوجه الإنساني the face of the human face? what! is the face of this face? is it another face in his face?!

متى يجب إضافة ألف التفريق -التي لا تلفظ- عند نهاية الكلمة؟

**ألف التفريق أو الفارقة:** هي ألف تزاد بعد واو الجماعة , للتفريق بينها وبين الواو التي هي من أصل الفعل والواو التي تكون في جمع المذكّر السالم عند حذف نونه للإضافة .
الأمثلة التالية للتوضيح:
- **كتب – كتبوا** الواو هنا واو الجماعة بحاجة إلى ألف تفريق . - **سما - يسمو** الواو هنا واو أصليّة ليست بحاجة إلى ألف تفريق . - **عالمون – عالمو المدينة** الواو هنا واو جمع المذكر السالم ليست بحاجة إلى ألف تفريق .
**مواضع ألف التفريق :** ألف التفريق لها ثلاثة مواضع رئيسة :
- الفعل الماضي المسند إلى واو الجماعة – **كتَبوا** - المضارع منه عند الجزم والنصب – يكتبون – **لم /لن يكتبوا** . - الأمر منه – **اكتبوا** .
ألف التفريق لا يمكن أن تأتي إلا في الأفعال المسندة إلى واو الجماعة المجردة, فلا محلّ لها في الأسماء , كـ

- The article *al-* always takes "a".
- Verbs of the VII. (infaʿala), VIII. (iftaʿala), IX. (ifʿalla) and X. stem (istafʿala) (as well as the XI., XII., XIII., XIV., and XV., which are extremely rare) have the *alif al-waṣl* of their perfect/past stem pronounced as "i".
- Verbs in the imperative mood have their *alif al-waṣl* pronounced as either "i" or "u". - Verbs whose present tense contain "i" or "a" (e.g. faʿala/yafʿ**a**lu) take the *alif al-waṣl* of the imperative as "i" (*ifʿal* : "do!"). - Some verbs whose present tense contain "u" in the middle (e.g. ḫaraǧa/yaḫr**u**ǧu) take the *alif al-waṣl* of the imperative as "u" (*uḫruǧ* : "get out!").
- As for nouns, they also usually take "i" (as *ibn* or *ism*). - Loanwords from other languages (e.g. Greek), however, may take "a" (as in *aflāṭūn* : "Plato") or "u" (as in *usṭuquss* : "element/letter").
In your example from al-Fātiḥā, the word in question (*ihdinā* : "guide us!") is an imperative from the verb hadā/yahdī. Since it contains "i" in its present tense, it takes "i" in its imperative.

We have two cases here:
- If what is after the أن لا/الَا is a verb this means the أن here أن الناصبة which targets verbs. In this case they have to combined in writing as in أَلَّا - If what is after the أن لا/الَا is a noun this means the أن here is أن المخففة which targets nouns. In this case they have to separated in writing as in أن لا
**The difference in the meaning**
- First case states hat the act of the verb mentioned is NOT allowed or forbidden.
Ex: I am telling my son
> قررت ألاّ تذهب الى اللعب اليوم
I decided that you are NOT going to the playground today
- Second case can be translated as "There is No .... "
Ex: I am telling my son
> قد اخبرتك أن لا جلسة لعب اليوم
I told you there is no playing session today.

At the beginning of speech, i.e. at the beginning of a new sentence or clause or any position that is preceded by a grammatical pause, the *hamzat al-waṣl* or *alif al-waṣl* is pronounced according to the following rules:
- The article *al-* always takes "a".
- Verbs of the VII. (*infaʿala*), VIII. (*iftaʿala*, IX. (*ifʿalla*) and X. stem (*istafʿala*) (as well as the XI., XII., XIII., XIV., and XV., which are extremely rare) have the *alif al-waṣl* of their perfect/past stem pronounced as "i".
- Verbs in the imperative mood have their *alif al-waṣl* pronounced as either "i" or "u". - Verbs whose present tense contain "i" or "a" (e.g. *faʿala/yafʿ**a**lu*) take the *alif al-waṣl* of the imperative as "i" (*ifʿal* : "do!"). - Some verbs whose present tense contain "u" in the middle (e.g. *ḫaraǧa/yaḫr**u**ǧu*) take the *alif al-waṣl* of the imperative as "u" (*uḫruǧ* : "get out!").
- As for nouns, they also usually take "i" (as *ibn* or *ism*).
Generally speaking, the reason for prefixing a *hamzat al-waṣl* or *alif al-waṣl* to a word is that the Arabic language avoids the existence of two consonant at the beginning of a word. Since verbs like *infaʿala* or nouns like *ibn* and imperatives like *uḫruǧ* would -- without a *alif al-waṣl* -- begin with two consonants, one is orthographically required to add a vowel. This vowel, then, is pronounced only if the word in question is alone in isolation or at the beginning of a sentence or after a grammatical pause.
There may be other words which take on a vowel for the same reason, i.e. to avoid two consonants at the beginning of the word, but they keep it under any circumstances. Such words are, for example, loanwords from other languages (e.g. Greek), which may take "a" (as in *aflāṭūn* : "Plato") or "u" (as in *usṭuquss* : "element/letter"). This, then, is called *hamzat al-qaṭʿ*.
In your example from al-Fātiḥā, the word in question (*ihdinā* : "guide us!") is an imperative from the verb hadā/yahdī. Since it contains "i" in its present tense, it takes "i" in its imperative.

You write: “Visually, there is nothing to distinguish the hamzat al-waṣl in any of these cases”. That is correct, at least in the maṣḥaf from which you have taken your image. This is because it follows the convention of vocalising the whole ṣūra as it would sound if it were read without any pauses. That is why اهدنا is written with waṣla over the first letter. But you can also find maṣāḥif where it is written with kasra, or with waṣla above and kasra below. These are different traditions of pointing the bare text. If you pause at the end of each ʼāya then you have to read /ʼihdinā/.

There are some prepositions in Arabic which need to be attached to the word they modify. Among them are بـ : *bi-* and لـ : *li-*. They are written together with the word, e.g. لِما / لِذلك (*li-ḏālika / li-mā*) and بِما / بِذلك (*bi-ḏālika / bi-mā*).
The preposition fī : في is not usually among this category. One would expect في ذلك : *fī ḏālika* as well as في ما : *fī ma* .
Why, however, do I sometimes find فيما : fīmā ? (But never فيذلك : fīḏālika...)
I am guessing that there is no difference in meaning between فيما : *fīmā* and في ما : *fī mā* . (However I once found some grammarian on the web writing in Arabic that there is in fact a difference -- I will try to find that site again and posit it here as reference.)
So, why is there this orthographical variety that allows attaching في : *fī* to ما : *mā* even though في : *fī* normally does not combine with the words it modifies?
Preposition fī in combination with mā

There are a few words that are exactly the same in Hebrew and Arabic. And there are others that are quite similar (e.g. no, *lo* and *la*, peace, *shalom* and *salaam*).
There is some information [here](http://dglnotes.com/notes/arabic-hebrew2.htm) and at a few other places.
Now I'd like to see an extended list with words that are exactly the same and words that are very similar. A list that will help me improve my knowledge of both languages. Ideally it will also indicate which language borrowed from which for each word (even if this is not always very clear) and around which point in history (e.g. Palestinian Arabic and Israeli Hebrew are borrowing heavily from each other these days, but borrowings must have taken place over the past millenia).
As it's probably not even possible to ever have a complete list, a good answer can simply point to such one or more of such lists elsewhere.

The sun letters احروف الشمسية are letters like ش and ل which use the tip of the tongue. It is much easier to pronounce a pronounce ash-shams than al-shams. Try saying both 10 times quickly, which one can you finish in the shortest time?
The moon letters الحروف اقمرية are letters which like ق which use the back of the tongue or ب which uses the lips. You don't run into pronunciation problems because different parts of your mouth are used, so you pronounce each letter.
The sun letters are ت ث د ذ ر ز س ش ص ض ط ظ ن
The moon letters are ء ب ج ح خ ع غ ف ق ك م ه و ي
Depending on who you ask ل could be either sun or moon. Egyptian speakers pronounce the ج as a hard 'g' like 'go', so it is a moon letter for them. Other places pronounce the ج as either a hard 'j' like 'jump' or a soft 'j' like the 's' in 'measure'. For these speakers, ج is a sun letter.

A trick we were thought in school to distinguish hamzat al-wasl. Which is putting the letter "و" before the word and pronounce it. like the word "ihdina", if you put the latter "و" before the word, it will become "wahdina", so it's hamzat wasel. notice we didn't pronounce the hamza.
But in other word like "*Imam""إمام*" if we put the letter "و" before the word and pronounce it, we're going to say it as "*wai'mam*" not "*wamam*", so it's *hamzat qate' "همزة قطع"*.

There are two parts of the question but, they are related: - To know the form of the number that comes before the noun, you should know the gender of the noun (whether it comes in plural or in singular, you should know the gender of its singular form) - To know the gender of the the plural nouns, it actually depends on the noun. For example, the noun "day", in Arabic, it is: > يوم (in singular, it is male) > > أيام (in plural, it is female)
However, and as I've mentioned, to put a count for this noun, you should follow the gender of the singular, which is male in our example. The rule of the numbers is: - If the number is between 3-10, the gender of the number should be the opposite of the gender of the noun. So as per our example, the number should be female. That's why we said: > ثلاثة أيام - If the number is between 13-19, the *ten* should be in the same gender, but the first digit should be in the opposite gender. For example: > خمسة عشر يوماً
To know the full rule of the numbers format, please, refer to [this explanation][1]. [1]: http://www.alargam.com/numbers/61.htm

From a poem of Imru' al-Qais (أمرؤ القيس):
> ألا لآ لا إلا ليء لا بث ........ولا لآ لا إلا لآليء من رحل
There are other examples, same letters but changing patterns and words:
> وكاف وكفكاف وكفي بكفها ......وكاف كفوف الودق من كفها انهمل
And this is an example from the poem "صوت صفير البلبل" of Al-asma'i (الأصمعي):
> فولولــت وولولــت ***ولــي ولــي ياويللـــــي
If this style of poetry has a name, I think this is just using paronomasia (الجناس) for multiple words.

This is called *[Pangram][1]* / *[جامع حروف][2]*. Here is examples of poetry:
1.
> صف خلق خود كمثل الشمس إذ بزغت *** يحظى الضجيع بها نجلاء معطار
2.
> هلا سكنت بذي ضغث فقد زعموا *** شخصت تطلب ظبيا راح مجتازا
3.
> اصبر على حفظ خضر واستشر فطنا *** وزج همك (قريب) بغداذ منثملا
[1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pangram [2]: https://ar.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%B9_%D8%AD%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%81

row.Text:
These are normally considered "short vowel marks" and are used (normally) for indefinite nouns, for example saying a Mosque would be Dammatain in defacto persona in most cases however saying "the Mosque" would actually be a damma in defacto persona.
For example:
> هاذا المسجدُ
"This is the Mosque", which ends in a Damma.
> هاذا مسجدٌ
"This is a Mosque", which ends in a Dammatain
It is good to note that the Alif on the end actually means something else again and can normally be used for direct objects (though it has other rules too). An example of a word that uses a Alif ending is:
> مرحباً
"Marhaban"
Which in this case is because of a particular rule in relation to the "a" ending on Marhaba.
But that is a much wider topic which involves the talking about how direct objects are used in relation to certain verbs etc etc (i.e. with use of "kam" meaning how much/many) and in certain phrases etc etc.
This is a good resource I used to understand the short vowel marks:
- [Fathatain][1] - [Dammatain][2] - [Kasratain][3]
Puts the meaning into super laymans terms to easily understand.
[1]: http://www.madinaharabic.com/Arabic_Reading_Course/Lessons/L000_006.html [2]: http://www.madinaharabic.com/Arabic_Reading_Course/Lessons/L000_008.html [3]: http://www.madinaharabic.com/Arabic_Reading_Course/Lessons/L000_007.html

The word for "hundred" is usually written مائة but is pronounced *mi'a*, as if it were written مئة. (It is sometimes written in the latter way, as it is pronounced, too.)
**References:**
* *An-Nafees, The 21st Century English-Arabic Dictionary*, Magdi Wahba (2000) gives for "hundred":
> مائة، مئة
(i.e. "مائة" is given first)
* *A new Arabic grammar of the written language*, Haywood & Nahmad, 2nd edition (1965) says:
> 100 مئة (also frequently written مائة but the *ʾalif* is not pronounced)
* *A Reference Grammar of Modern Standard Arabic*, Ryding (2005) says:
> The word for "hundred" in Arabic is *miʾa*, spelled both as مئة and مائة.
* *The Hans Wehr Dictionary of Modern Written Arabic*, ed. Cowan (1979) says:
> مئة, also مائة *miʾa* [...] hundred

First it should be said that *taʾ marbuta* is not the only marker of feminine words - there are some other forms that mark the feminine:
* ‏-اء, for example النساء الشقراء *the blond women* (but note غناء is masculine) * ‏-ىٰ, for example (but note مبنى is masculine) * ‏-ا, for example الدنيا جميلة *the world is beautiful*
(in the cases of the masculine nouns, note that the final اء or ى is part of the root, not part of the وزن/suffix)
There are a huge number of nouns that follow those patterns, so it is not helpful to try to list them all.
Next there are some large categories of feminine nouns that do not necessarily follow a pattern, so again trying to list them will not be fruitful:
* Cities are considered feminine (because مدينة is feminine) * Most countries are feminine * Women's names are, naturally, feminine (e.g. زينب جميلة *Zeinab is beautiful*) * Also nouns whose meanings refer to women are feminine (بنت، أخت، حامل، عروس، أم, عاقر، عجوز). * Parts of the body that come in pairs are usually feminine (e.g. رجل طويلة *long leg*)
Finally there are nouns that do not fit into any of the above categories, but are nonetheless feminine. The ones I'm aware of (please mention any more you know in comments!) are:
* نفس *self, soul* * خمر *wine* * حرب *war* * دار *house* * نار *fire* * ريح *wind* * أرض *earth, land* * شمس *sun* * بئر *well* * كأس *cup* * سن *tooth, age* * فأس *axe* * قوس *bow* * نعل *sandal*
For completeness I should mention there are also a small number of nouns (such as حال *situation*, ملح salt etc.) that can be either masculine or feminine; I won't list those here but I suggest that asking for those would be a good topic for another question.

There are three signs for feminine words in Arabic: ta' merbuta (قائمة)، alef memduda (حمراء), alef meqsura (حبلى).
There are masculine words with those signs : علامة, ثلاثاء, خنثى. There are feminine words without those signs: هند، كتف، عناق.

row.Text:
In the study of Arabic grammar, there are several aspects that deal with the gender of a word. There are rules such as:
- Words are assumed to be masculine by default - Words that end with ta-marbuwta, or alif maqsurah, are feminine - The names of body parts that we have two of, are feminine - Some words are "fake feminine," i.e. the word has some indications of the first two rules above, but are masculine in reality (such as the name "hamzah") - Some words are feminine in reality (eg. nisaa) and therefore, in grammar
This is not an exhaustive list. What I am particularly interested in is a special category that follows none of the rules or guidelines above; it is referred to as "feminine because the Arabs said so." One of my Arabic teachers mentioned that this category was part of the language from the beginning, and nobody knows why (hence the name).
He also said that this is a short list of words (no more than a dozen or so), and a static list (it doesn't change over time as the language changes).
Is there a complete list of these words?

As others have mentioned, the *five nouns* are as follows: * أب *father* * أخ *brother* * حم *father-in-law* * فم *mouth* * ذو *possessor, "the one with"* and the word هن *genitals* is associated with them (because it *can* follow the pattern described below) but is not normally considered one (because it can also behave as a normal noun). So, what makes them different from other nouns? As others have noted, it has to do with case markings: in *some* circumstances these nouns have long vowels to mark their case. Under normal circumstances, when the words are used independently (i.e. they are not the first word or مضاف in an إضافة construction, and do not have a pronoun suffix), they behave like normal nouns, and take short vowel endings to mark case: * Nominative (مرفوع):‎ أخٌ *ʾaxun*, الأخُ *al-axw* * Accusative (منصوب):‎ أخاً *ʾaxan*, الاخَ *al-axa* * Genitive (مجرور):‎ أخٍ *ʾaxin*, الأخِ *al-axi* For example: رأى الأبُ أخاً *The father saw a brother* However, when these nouns are in first position (مضاف) in an إضافة construction, or have a pronoun suffix, the vowel becomes long: * Nominative (مرفوع):‎ أخو *ʾaxuu* * Accusative (منصوب):‎ أخا *ʾaxaa* * Genitive (مجرور):‎ أخي *ʾaxii* For example: رأى أخو حميه فماها *The father of his father-in-law saw her mouth*

Under normal circumstances, when the words are used independently (i.e. they are not the first word or مضاف in an إضافة construction, and do not have a pronoun suffix), they behave like normal nouns, and take short vowel endings to mark case: * Nominative (مرفوع):‎ أخٌ *ʾaxun*, الأخُ *al-axw* * Accusative (منصوب):‎ أخاً *ʾaxan*, الاخَ *al-axa* * Genitive (مجرور):‎ أخٍ *ʾaxin*, الأخِ *al-axi* For example: رأى الأبُ أخاً *The father saw a brother* However, when these nouns are in first position (مضاف) in an إضافة construction, or have a pronoun suffix, the vowel becomes long: * Nominative (مرفوع):‎ أخو *ʾaxuu* * Accusative (منصوب):‎ أخا *ʾaxaa* * Genitive (مجرور):‎ أخي *ʾaxii* For example: رأى أخو حميه فاها *The father of his father-in-law saw her mouth*

The sun letters (الحروف الشمسية) are letters like `ش` and `ل` which use the tip of the tongue. It is much easier to pronounce `ash-shams` than `al-shams`. Try saying both 10 times quickly, which one can you finish in the shortest time?
The moon letters (الحروف القمرية) are letters like `ق` that uses the back of the tongue or `ب` that uses the lips. You don't run into pronunciation problems because different parts of your mouth are used, so you pronounce each letter.
The sun letters are:
ت ث د ذ ر ز س ش ص ض ط ظ ن
The moon letters are:
ء ب ج ح خ ع غ ف ق ك م ه و ي
Depending on who you ask `ل` could be either sun or moon. Egyptian speakers pronounce the `ج` as a hard 'g' like 'go', so it is a moon letter for them. Other places pronounce the `ج` as either a hard 'j' like 'jump' or a soft 'j' like the 's' in 'measure'. For these speakers, `ج` is a sun letter.

Most often on the web and also in books the letter 'و' is written with no space after it. For example: ذهب شهر رمضان وجاء العيد.
If this letter is considered a word by itself, then is it not more appropriate to separate it by a space from the next word?
Should I type a space after the letter Waw?

**Simple sentences**
The subject (المبتدأ) is who/what the sentence is talking about. The predicate (الخبر) is the information the sentence gives about the subject.
الولدُ طويلٌ.
The sentence is talking about `the boy` (المبتدأ = الولد) and the information it gives about the boy is that he `is tall` (الخبر = طويلٌ).
الولدُ يأكلُ تفاحةً.
The sentence is talking about `the boy` (المبتدأ = الولد) , and the information it gives about the boy is that he `is eating an apple` (الخبر = يأكلُ تفاحةٌ).
يأكلُ الولدُ تفاحةً.
Sometimes the sentence uses a different word order, but `the boy` is still المبتدأ and `is eating an apple` is still الخبر.
**Compound Sentences**
A compound sentence is a way of combining two sentences together using conjunctions. This could give us multiple subjects and a common predicate, a common subject with multiple predicates, or multiple subjects each with their own predicate.
الأولادُ والبناتُ طويلونَ.
This sentence has multiple subjects الأولادُ and البناتُ, but only one predicate طويلونَ.
الولد يشاهدُ تلفزيونَ ويأكلُ تفاحةَ.
This sentence has a single predicate الولدُ and two predicates يشاهدُ تلفزيونَ and يأكلُ تفاحةَ.
**Complex Sentences**
Usually everyone knows who الولد is, but sometimes some extra information is needed to know which ولد we are talking about. In these cases a relative clause may be used, making a complex sentence.
الولد الذي لعبتُ معه طويلً.
The predicate of the overall sentence is طويلٌ. In its most basic form, the subject is الولد, but if we want to include every word in the sentence, then the subject is الولد الذي لعبتُ معه. In other words, complex sentences have only one مبتدأ and one خبر just like simple sentences.
**Compound Complex**
Compound complex sentences use conjunctions to combine sentences with relative clauses. Their analysis is a natural extension of the ideas presented above.
**What if we wanted to analyze the relative clause?**
The complex sentence
الولد الذي لعبتُ معه طويلً
is a way of combining two sentences. The overall sentence
الولدُ طويلٌ.
and a sentence hidden inside the relative clause.
لعبتُ معه.
The subject of this sentence is أنا (hidden in the conjugation of the verb) and the predicate is لعبتُ معه, but these assignments have nothing to do with المبتدأ and الخبر of the overall sentence.

In Arabic, prepositions and conjunctions that are made up of only one letter are always written attached to the next word. This is the case with 'و', but you'd do the same with, for example, 'ب' and 'ل'.
On the other hand, prepositions and conjunctions that are made up of *more* than one letter (e.g. 'من' or 'إن') would always be written separately, with a space between it and the next word.

الافعال الخمسة في كل فعل مضارع اتصل به `ألف الاثنين` أو `واو الجماعة` أو `ياء المخاطبة`.
العدد خمسة جاء من كونها خمسة حالات:
1. التلميذان يدرسان – للغائبين 2. أنتما تدرسان – للمخاطَبَيْن 3. هم يدرسون – للغائِبيْن 4. أنتم تدرسون – للمخاطَبِيْن 5. أنتِ تدرسين – للمخاطبة
فكما ترى `ألف الإثنين` وردت مرتين مرة للمخاطب ومرة للغائب. وكذلك `واو الجماعة`.

The translations of those words are:
1. The Accusative case -> حالة النصب 2. The Nominative case -> حالة الرفع 3. The Genitive case -> حالة الجر 4. The Jussive case -> حالة الجزم 4. Non-Declinable -> مبني 5. Declinable -> معرب

هذا البيت من قصيدة امرؤ القيس:
> قفا نبك من ذِكرى حبيب ومنزل | بسِقطِ اللِّوى بينَ الدَّخول > فحَوْملِ
ما معناه؟
ما معنى: "قفا نبك من ذِكرى حبيب ومنزل | بسِقطِ اللِّوى بينَ الدَّخول فحَوْملِ"؟

row.Text:
**Simple sentences**
The subject (المبتدأ) is who/what the sentence is talking about. The predicate (الخبر) is the information the sentence gives about the subject.
الولدُ طويلٌ.
The sentence is talking about `the boy` (المبتدأ = الولد) and the information it gives about the boy is that he `is tall` (الخبر = طويلٌ).
الولدُ يأكلُ تفاحةً.
The sentence is talking about `the boy` (المبتدأ = الولد) , and the information it gives about the boy is that he `is eating an apple` (الخبر = يأكلُ تفاحةٌ).
يأكلُ الولدُ تفاحةً.
Sometimes the sentence uses a different word order, but `the boy` is still المبتدأ and `is eating an apple` is still الخبر.
**Compound Sentences**
A compound sentence is a way of combining two sentences together using conjunctions. This could give us multiple subjects and a common predicate, a common subject with multiple predicates, or multiple subjects each with their own predicate.
الأولادُ والبناتُ طويلونَ.
This sentence has multiple subjects الأولادُ and البناتُ, but only one predicate طويلونَ.
الولد يشاهدُ تلفزيونَ ويأكلُ تفاحةَ.
This sentence has a single subject الولدُ and two predicates يشاهدُ تلفزيونَ and يأكلُ تفاحةَ.
**Complex Sentences**
Usually everyone knows who الولد is, but sometimes some extra information is needed to know which ولد we are talking about. In these cases a relative clause may be used, making a complex sentence.
الولد الذي لعبتُ معه طويلً.
The predicate of the overall sentence is طويلٌ. In its most basic form, the subject is الولد, but if we want to include every word in the sentence, then the subject is الولد الذي لعبتُ معه. In other words, complex sentences have only one مبتدأ and one خبر just like simple sentences.
**Compound Complex**
Compound complex sentences use conjunctions to combine sentences with relative clauses. Their analysis is a natural extension of the ideas presented above.
**What if we wanted to analyze the relative clause?**
The complex sentence
الولد الذي لعبتُ معه طويلً
is a way of combining two sentences. The overall sentence
الولدُ طويلٌ.
and a sentence hidden inside the relative clause.
لعبتُ معه.
The subject of this sentence is أنا (hidden in the conjugation of the verb) and the predicate is لعبتُ معه, but these assignments have nothing to do with المبتدأ and الخبر of the overall sentence.

row.Text: As others have mentioned, the *five nouns* are as follows: * أب *father* * أخ *brother* * حم *father-in-law* * فم *mouth* * ذو *possessor, "the one with"* and the word هن *genitals* is associated with them (because it *can* follow the pattern described below) but is not normally considered one of them (although some sources do occasionally refer to [الاسماء الستة][1] *the six nouns*), because it can also follow the standard noun patterns. (However, this is also true of فم - at least in modern usage.) So, what makes them different from other nouns? As others have noted, it has to do with case markings: in *some* circumstances these nouns have long vowels to mark their case. Under normal circumstances, when the words are used independently (i.e. they are not the first word or مضاف in an إضافة construction, and do not have a pronoun suffix), they behave like normal nouns, and take short vowel endings to mark case: * Nominative (مرفوع):‎ أخٌ *ʾaxun*, الأخُ *al-axu* * Accusative (منصوب):‎ أخاً *ʾaxan*, الاخَ *al-axa* * Genitive (مجرور):‎ أخٍ *ʾaxin*, الأخِ *al-axi* For example: رأى الأبُ أخاً *The father saw a brother* However, when these nouns are in first position (مضاف) in an إضافة construction, or have a pronoun suffix, the vowel becomes long: * Nominative (مرفوع):‎ أخو *ʾaxuu* * Accusative (منصوب):‎ أخا *ʾaxaa* * Genitive (مجرور):‎ أخي *ʾaxii* For example: رأى أخو حميه فاها *The brother of his father-in-law saw her mouth*. Here أخ is مضاف and nominative, so it becomes أخو; ‎حم has the pronoun suffix ‏-‍ه and is genitive so it becomes حمي;‎ فم has the pronoun suffix ‏-‍ها and is accusative so it becomes فا (the م of فم is dropped whenever it has a long vowel suffix). Note that these long-vowel forms only happen in certain situations - they do not happen if: * The word is not مضاف and has no pronoun suffix, or * the pronoun suffix is ‏-ي ‎(هذا أبي *This is my father*), or * the word is plural (هؤلاء إخوتي *These are my brothers*), or * the word is used in a diminutive form (وصل أخيو محمود *Mahmood's little brother arrived*). [1]: http://www.almaany.com/ar/dict/ar-ar/%D9%81%D9%88/

It is widely accepted in famous exegeses like [ibn Katheer](http://www.qtafsir.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2086&Itemid=99) that [verse 18](http://quran.com/43/18) of Surat az-Zukhruf refers to females. Yet the verse is written as if it is referring to something masculine.
> ![أَوَمَن يُنَشَّأُ فِي الْحِلْيَةِ وَهُوَ فِي الْخِصَامِ غَيْرُ مُبِينٍ ](http://i.stack.imgur.com/cZBQV.png)
> (Do they then like for Allah) a creature who is brought up in adornments (wearing silk and gold ornaments, i.e. women), and in dispute cannot make herself clear?
> [translation by Muhsin Khan]
As this verse is talking about females exclusively, I would have expected to see تنشؤ instead of ينشؤ , and هي in place of هو .
Is there a grammatical principle that explains why this is the case?
Why are females referred to in the masculine form in this verse from Surat az-Zukhruf?

**Linguistic Explanation:**
The verb `ينشؤ` and the pronoun `هو` in this verse follow `من` which is gender-neutral number-neutral. It's the same to where Prophet wives are mentioned:
> **ومن يقنت** منكن لله ورسوله وتعمل صالحا نؤتها أجرها مرتين وأعتدنا > لها رزقا كريما
and so:
> يانساء النبي **من يأت** منكن بفاحشة مبينة يضاعف لها العذاب ضعفين وكان > ذلك على الله يسيرا
--- For example, you can say to a group of female students:
من يدرس منكن ينجح / who will study *(masculine single)* among you *(feminine plural)*, he *(masculine single)* will succeed.

The verb `ينشؤ` and the pronoun `هو` in this verse follow `من` which is *gender-neutral* and *number-neutral*. It's the same to where Prophet wives are mentioned:
> يانساء النبي **من يأت** منكن بفاحشة مبينة يضاعف لها العذاب ضعفين وكان > ذلك على الله يسيرا > > O wives of the prophet! **whoever** of you **commits** an open indecency, the punishment shall be increased to her doubly; and this is easy to Allah.
and so:
> **ومن يقنت** منكن لله ورسوله وتعمل صالحا نؤتها أجرها مرتين وأعتدنا > لها رزقا كريما > >**And whoever** of you **is obedient** to Allah and His Apostle and does good, We will give to her reward doubly, and We have prepared for her an honorable sustenance.
--- For example, you can say to a group of female students:
من يدرس منكن ينجح / who will study *(masculine single)* among you *(feminine plural)*, he *(masculine single)* will succeed.

row.Comment: Add أولو; tweak a few things
row.Text:
There are a few words which have letters that are not pronounced.
* أُولو (a plural form of ذو, or at least used with that meaning). The first و is [not pronounced](http://www.almaany.com/ar/dict/ar-ar/%D8%A3%D9%88%D9%84%D9%88/), so it is *uluu* rather than *uuluu*.
* The word for "hundred" is often written مائة but is pronounced *mi'a*, as if it were written مئة. (It is also written in the latter way, as it is pronounced, too.)
**References:**
* [*Al-Maany*](http://www.almaany.com/ar/dict/ar-ar/%D8%A3%D9%88%D9%84%D9%88/) (Online Arabic-Arabic dictionary) says
> أولو: [...] تُرسم بالواو الأولى ولا تُنطق
* *An-Nafees, The 21st Century English-Arabic Dictionary*, Magdi Wahba (2000) gives for "hundred":
> مائة، مئة
(i.e. "مائة" is given first)
* *A new Arabic grammar of the written language*, Haywood & Nahmad, 2nd edition (1965) says:
> 100 مئة (also frequently written مائة but the *ʾalif* is not pronounced)
* *A Reference Grammar of Modern Standard Arabic*, Ryding (2005) says:
> The word for "hundred" in Arabic is *miʾa*, spelled both as مئة and مائة.
* *The Hans Wehr Dictionary of Modern Written Arabic*, ed. Cowan (1979) says:
> مئة, also مائة *miʾa* [...] hundred
and
> أولو *ulū* (pl. of ذو) owners, possessors [...]
من المذاهب النحوية الأكثر اشتهارا وانتشارا مذهبين هما: المذهب الكوفي والمذهب البصري، سؤالي هو أي من المذهبين أكثر استخداما في التعليم في الدول العربية؟

كان هناك بعض اللهجات القريبة جداً من اللغة العربية الفصيحة قبل الإسلام. لكن اللغة الفصحى كانت هي اللغة السائدة في الشعر والخطابة والمراسلات حتى أن القرآن الكريم نزل باللغة العربية الفصحى. معظم المراجع تقول إن اللهجات بدأت بالانتشار قبيل القرن التاسع عشر

وهناك عاملان اشتركا بنشوء اللهجات:
الأول هو [الاحتلال والانتداب][1] من عدة شعوب ودول غربية مما أدى إلى اختلاط اللغات ودخول كلمات غريبة إلى مفردات اللغة العربية
والسبب الثاني هو دخول شعوب مختلفة ومن شتى بقاع الأرض بالإسلام واختلاط وتزاوج هذه الشعوب

مع الأسف, في الوقت الحالي فإن للعربية كثيراً من اللهجات العامية المختلفة التي ليس لها قواعد نحوية أو صرفية أو معاجم لمفرداتها وكلماتها أو طريقة لكتابتها وفي الحقيقة, تُقسم اللهجات العامية في الوطن العربي حسب المدينة أو القرية وليس حسب البلد فحسب. ولكن لا يزال العرب معروفين بالتحدث بلغة واحدة كون أغلبهم يفهمون بعضهم بالرغم من تعدد لهجاتهم. [1]: http://raseef22.com/culture/2015/04/27/5-languages-with-most-impact-on-arabic-language/
Why are females referred to in the masculine form in this Qur'anic verse?

From a poem of Imru' al-Qais (أمرؤ القيس):
> ألا لا لآ إلا لآلئ لابِثٍ.........ولا لا لآ إلاَّ لآلئ من رَحَلْ
There are other examples, same letters but changing patterns and words:
> وَكَاف وكِفَكَاف وَكَفِّي بِكَفِّهَا ...... وَكَاف كَفُوْف الْوَدَق مِن كَفِّهَا انْهَمَل
And this is an example from the poem "صوت صفير البلبل" of Al-asma'i (الأصمعي):
> فَوَلْـوَلَـتْ وَوَلْـوَلَــت ..... وَلي وَلي يَـاوَيْـلَلِــي
If this style of poetry has a name, I think this is just using paronomasia (الجناس) for multiple words.

In translation, you should choose a word with a unique meaning. the main meaning of حفظ is saving/memorizing so choosing it for Conservation is a bad idea. إنحفاظ has nearly one translation which is Conservation. Using إنحفاظ eliminate the meaning ambiguity.

For مصونية, it is also has a unique meaning which is good, but its verb is متعدي too : صينت الطاقة.

The rule is related to the word **Ma** when followed by a Genitive tool like **Fi** and **Min** and **A'an**.
- If the word **Ma** occur as relative pronoun in that case we can attach or detach the tow words, and the separation is better, and we can't remove the **ا** from **Ma** so we write **فيما** and **في ما** - The second case is when the word **Ma** is for asking a question, in that case we must attach the tow words and we can remove or let the **ا** of **Ma**, in that case we can write **فيم** and **فيما** and **عم** and **عما**

يجدر الإشارة إلى أن المدرسة البصرية تعتبر هي السابقة في الدراسات النحوية، كما لا ينسى الإسهام الكوفي الذي أدى إلى نضج الدرس النحوي واكتماله، وذلك من خلال إكمال الجهد البصري باتباع المنهج التوسعي في السماع والقياس الذي عدَّ أقرب إلى المنهج الوصفي الحديث في الدراسات اللغوية، وهذا بدوره أدى إلى وجود الخلاف بين المدرستين، بالإضافة إلى التنافس العلمي نتيجة مواقف الخلفاء العباسيين وميلهم إلى الكوفيين، والعصبية الإقليمية، وهذا بدوره طال المصطلح النحوي في التعبير عن الموضوعات النحوية على أنَّ المصطلح النحوي البصري هو الذي استخدم واشتهر، ولم يشتهر من المصطلح الكوفي إلا النعت وعطف النسق، وقد انعكس ذلك على النحاة المتأخرين من .المدارس النحوية البغدادية والمصرية والأندلسية
لذلك فأغلب الظن أن المذهب البصري هو الرائج حاليا مع الاستئناس بالمذهب الكوفي في بعض القضايا. لا يمكن الجزم في كيفية تعامل كل قطر عربي مع المذاهب النحوية لكن جدول الإختلافات في المصطلحات يمكننا من التعرف على نسبة تأثر المنهج التعليمي الذي سلكناه بالمدرستين:

كما نلاحظ أغلب المصطلحات المستعملة هي مصطلحات بصرية بما في ذلك الحركات.

Are dual verbs and nouns (المثنى) used often in daily conversation between native speakers? In my experience, I feel that I do not hear it often (in MSA and colloquial context).
Are dual verbs and nouns (المثنى) used often in daily conversation between native speakers?

In Egyptian (Cairo) dialect the dual is actually widely used, not only for natural pairs (rigleen ‘legs’, ʼideen ‘hands’, ʽeneen ‘eyes’), but also with ordinary words like beteen ‘two houses’, kitabeen ‘two books’. But this is true only of nouns; there are no dual forms for verbs or adjectives or pronouns.
The use of the dual is discussed in some detail in T.F. Mitchell, “Colloquial Arabic: The living language of Egypt”, pp. 41-42.

In Classical Arabic, there is no way to avoid dual form.
Some colloquial dialects of Arabic has dropped the dual form replacing it with plural form but this is nothing to do with Classical Arabic Native Speaking.

**Short Answer:**
`الشعر` is Poetry. `القصيدة` is a Poem, a set of successive lines called `أبيات`, each line is `بيت`.

**Short Answer:**

**Long Answer:**
(الشعر) is any speech that has a musical pattern (بحر) ending in defined letters (قافية)
(الشعر المنثور) is any speech has the same ways of (الشعر) in influencing and imagination, rhymed (مسجوع) but respects not known musical patterns (بحور الشعر).

row.Text:
First it should be said that *taʾ marbuta* is not the only marker of feminine words - there are some other forms that mark the feminine:
* ‏-اء, for example النساء الشقراء *the blond women* (but note غناء is masculine) * ‏-ىٰ, for example ذكرى شخصية *personal memory* (but note مبنى is masculine) * ‏-ا, for example الدنيا جميلة *the world is beautiful*
(in the cases of the masculine nouns, note that the final اء or ى is part of the root, not part of the وزن/suffix)
There are a huge number of nouns that follow those patterns, so it is not helpful to try to list them all.
Next there are some large categories of feminine nouns that do not necessarily follow a pattern, so again trying to list them will not be fruitful:
* Cities are considered feminine (because مدينة is feminine) * Most countries are feminine * Women's names are, naturally, feminine (e.g. زينب جميلة *Zeinab is beautiful*) * Also nouns whose meanings refer to women are feminine (بنت، أخت، حامل، عروس، أم, عاقر، عجوز). * Parts of the body that come in pairs are usually feminine (e.g. رجل طويلة *long leg*)
Finally there are nouns that do not fit into any of the above categories, but are nonetheless feminine. The ones I'm aware of (please mention any more you know in comments!) are:
* نفس *self, soul* * حرب *war* * دار *house* * نار *fire* * ريح *wind* * أرض *earth, land* * شمس *sun* * بئر *well* * كأس *cup* * سن *tooth, age* * فأس *axe* * قوس *bow* * نعل *sandal*
For completeness I should mention there are also a small number of nouns (such as حال *situation*, ملح salt etc.) that can be either masculine or feminine; for those, see [this question](http://arabic.stackexchange.com/q/136/70).

I have always wondered since for example I speak Iraqi Arabic is my native dialect and I still use it everyday, even more than English. However I recently saw a video where a woman was talking in a Moroccan accent and I barely understood what she was saying, it would have been so much easier for me to understand English (my second language) than her Arabic which is supposed to be my first language.
This is also very apparent in my sister who wasn't exposed much to Arabic dialects and accents, she can barely understand much outside of Iraqi and Egyptian arabic.
Not just that, but from a grammatical point of view, Iraqi Arabic should be a language of it's own. An example: In MSA, the question "What are you doing?" would translate to >ماذا تفل؟
But in Iraqi, we would say: >شْدَسّوّي؟
So my question is, why aren't the dialects considered different languages?

In the science of linguistics the words "language" and "dialect" do not have any generally accepted meaning. These terms belong more to the realm of politics. You are right to say that different forms of spoken Arabic are not mutually comprehensible. On the other hand, the Arab countries are connected by a more-or-less standardised shared written language in the form of High Arabic (العربية الفصحى). There exists thus a situation of so-called diglossia, where a shared written language coexists with a large number of different spoken languages/dialects.

I'm re-posting a great response to the same question from Dilworth Parkinson, Professor of Arabic at Brigham Young University, posted to the ARABIC-L email listserve. I am copy-pasting because there is no link.
---- Date: 24 Feb 2013
From:Dil Parkinson <dil@byu.edu>
Subject:wa- as a standalone character
This is one of those areas where actual practice and 'the rules' don't necessarily coincide, and where there is a kind of cline between patterns that appear simply to be typos all the way to very acceptable alternatives. I looked at the quantitative results for wa- standing alone in arabiCorpus and found, first, that it is quite common for wa- to have a space after it before numbers and punctuation (quotation marks and the like which are placed around a word without the wa-). When I ran a search just on standalone wa- before other Arabic letters (excluding the numbers and the punctuation), I got the following results for Al-Ghad (a Jordanian paper) and Al-Tajdid (a Moroccan paper):
Al-Ghad: 7.41 per 100,000
Tajdid: 271.12 per 100,000
Clearly, Mustafa's insight in the above message is accurate: the amount of standalone wa- in Jordan could be considered random errors, but the pattern for Morocco indicates that it is a common and valid choice. This is over 35 times more common in the Moroccan paper than in the Jordanian one, a major difference that implies entirely different attitudes toward the form.
I then decided to look at all the papers for standalone wa- (i.e. wa- followed by a space) where the next word starts with Alif lam (normally the definite article). I got the following surprising results:
Tajdid (Morocco): 79.18 per 100,000
Thawra (Syria): 65.36 per 100,000
Ahram (Egypt): 4.18 per 100,000
Shuruq (Egypt): 4.26 per 100,000
Watan (Kuwait): 2.34 per 100,000
AlGhad02 (Jordan): 2.38 per 100,000
Al-Ghad01 (Jordan): 2.18 per 100,000
Al-Masri Al-Yawm (Egypt): 0.76 per 100,000
Al-Hayat96 (London): 0.37 per 100,000
Al-Hayat97 (London): 0.32 per 100,000
Of note here:
1. Surprisingly, Syria is patterning much more closely with Morocco than with all the other countries for which I have evidence, which are much closer to it geographically than Morocco.
2. There is a very striking consistency in the other data. I have two separate years for al-Hayat, and two for Al-Ghad, and each has an almost identical pattern with the other. Two of the Egyptian papers also pattern very closely together.
3. Except for Syrian paper, the other papers are 20 times to over 200 times less likely to use the standalone wa-, compared to the Moroccan paper. For those who would like to see some of this data themselves, you need to use regular expressions in the transliteration box of arabiCorpus. To look for examples of standalone wa- (i.e. followed by a space) where the following word starts with alif lam, choose 'string' as the part of speech, choose a particular paper to look at, and search for:
\bw Al
\b means a word break. Make sure to do the capitalization right.
If you want to search for standalone wa- no matter what is following it, again choose 'string', and search for:
\bw\b
If you want to search for standalone wa- followed by any alphabetic letter, but not numbers or punctuation, then choose 'string' and search for:
\bw [AbtVjHxdvrzspSDTZcgfqklmnhwyLEM]
You need to be fairly patient for these searches to go through. Of course, any of them can be varied in a large number of ways to tweak the results. Once the results come back, you can see the ratio per 100,000 on the first page (as well as the actual number of forms found), but you need to click on 'Citations' or 'Word Forms' to see the actual examples it found.
Since many of the papers have data for exactly one year, the actual numbers are fairly interpretable: if there are about 350 actual forms in a year, that means you are going to see a standalone wa- about once a day; if about 700 then about twice a day, etc. The Moroccan and Kuwaiti papers represent about a half of a year, so for them you would need to double the actual numbers found to get the same insight.
If you made it this far, I hope you enjoyed it.
dil
